title: iBudget Waiver (Florida Medicaid Waiver)
shortDescription: Florida's home and community-based waiver providing funding for therapies, respite, personal care, and supports not covered by Medicaid.
description: The iBudget Waiver is Florida's Medicaid Home and Community-Based Services waiver for individuals with developmental disabilities, including autism. It provides funding for services and supports that help people live in their communities rather than institutions. Services include therapies, respite care, personal care assistance, specialized equipment, behavioral support, and more. The waiver is managed by the Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD).
whoQualifies: Florida residents diagnosed with autism, cerebral palsy, spina bifida, intellectual disability, or Prader-Willi Syndrome
Diagnosis must have occurred before age 18 (even if now an adult)
Requires APD enrollment and determination of developmental disability
All ages qualify - children, teens, and adults
whatIsCovered: Personal Care Assistance (help with daily living activities)
Residential habilitation (group home or supported living)
Therapy services (speech, OT, PT not covered by Medicaid)
Assistive technology and specialized medical equipment
howToApply: Contact the Agency for Persons with Disabilities (APD) at 1-866-APD-CARES
Complete APD enrollment application online at apdcares.org
Provide autism diagnosis documentation showing onset before age 18
Apply for Florida Medicaid if not already enrolled
Once approved, get placed on the waiver waitlist
Wait times vary - critical needs may be prioritized

budgetAmounts.tier_1: $15,000 - $35,000 per year for individuals with lower support needs
budgetAmounts.tier_2: $35,000 - $55,000 per year for moderate support needs
budgetAmounts.tier_3: $55,000+ per year for highest support needs
budgetAmounts.note: Budget amounts determined by assessment of individual needs

floridaSpecificInfo: Florida has a waitlist for the iBudget Waiver - wait times vary by region and need level
Crisis situations may qualify for expedited enrollment
Budgets are individualized based on assessed needs
Families have flexibility to choose services within their budget
Must have a support coordinator to help manage services
Budgets renew annually and can be adjusted based on changing needs

commonQuestions.question: How long is the waitlist for the iBudget Waiver?
commonQuestions.answer: Wait times vary significantly by region and individual needs. Some people wait months, others years. Crisis situations receive priority.

commonQuestions.question: Can I use iBudget funds to pay family members as caregivers?
commonQuestions.answer: Yes, in many cases you can hire family members (except spouses or legal guardians) as personal care assistants through the waiver.

commonQuestions.question: What happens if my child turns 18?
commonQuestions.answer: The waiver continues into adulthood. Adult services focus more on employment support, independent living, and community integration.

commonQuestions.question: Can I have both Medicaid and the iBudget Waiver?
commonQuestions.answer: Yes! You must have Medicaid to qualify for iBudget. The waiver covers additional services not included in regular Medicaid.
